etymologies: Middle English: from Old French trier ‘sift’, of unknown origin. Sense 1 of the noun dates from the early 17th century

notes.text: In practice, there is little discernible difference in meaning between try to plus infinitive (we should try to help them) and try and plus infinitive (we should try and help them), but there is a difference in formality, with try to being regarded as more formal than try and. Beyond the issue of formality, the construction try and is grammatically odd, in that it cannot be inflected for tense—that is, sentences like she tried and fix it or they are trying and renew their visa are not acceptable, while their equivalents she tried to fix it or they are trying to renew their visa obviously are. For this reason, try and is best regarded as a fixed idiom used only in its infinitive and imperative form. See also and

definitions: make an attempt or effort to do something

examples.text: he tried to regain his breath
I started to try and untangle the mystery
I decided to try writing fiction
three times he tried the maneuver and three times he failed
none of them tried very hard

shortDefinitions: make attempt or effort to do something

definitions: use, test, or do (something new or different) in order to see if it is suitable, effective, or pleasant

examples.text: everyone wanted to know if I'd tried jellied eel
these methods are tried and tested
they decided to try for another baby

definitions: visit (a place) or contact (a person) in order to find someone or obtain something

examples.text: she's not here, but you could try her room
I tried the library but it was out on loan
he tried all her friends but no one knew where she was

shortDefinitions: visit place or attempt to contact

definitions: push or pull (a door or window) to determine whether it is locked

examples.text: I tried the doors, but they were locked

shortDefinitions: push or pull door or window to determine whether it is locked

examples.text: he was arrested and tried for the murder

definitions: investigate and decide (a case or issue) in a formal trial

examples.text: such cases must be tried by a jury

shortDefinitions: investigate and decide case or issue in formal trial

definitions: make severe demands on (a person or a quality, typically patience)

examples.text: Mary tried everyone's patience to the limit

definitions: smooth (roughly planed wood) with a plane to give an accurately flat surface.
shortDefinitions: smooth roughly planed wood with plane to give accurately flat surface

notes.text: In practice, there is little discernible difference in meaning between try to plus infinitive (we should try to help them) and try and plus infinitive (we should try and help them), but there is a difference in formality, with try to being regarded as more formal than try and. Beyond the issue of formality, the construction try and is grammatically odd, in that it cannot be inflected for tense—that is, sentences like she tried and fix it or they are trying and renew their visa are not acceptable, while their equivalents she tried to fix it or they are trying to renew their visa obviously are. For this reason, try and is best regarded as a fixed idiom used only in its infinitive and imperative form. See also and

definitions: an effort to accomplish something; an attempt

examples.text: Mitterrand was elected president on his third try

definitions: an act of doing, using, or testing something new or different to see if it is suitable, effective, or pleasant

examples.text: they should give the idea a try

shortDefinitions: act of trying something new or different to see if it is suitable or pleasant

definitions: an act of touching the ball down behind the opposing goal line, scoring points and entitling the scoring side to a goal kick.
shortDefinitions: act of touching ball down behind opposing goal line
